articles.headline: Two Former Traders Found Guilty in Libor Manipulation Case
articles.snippet: The verdict against the two former Rabobank traders, Anthony Allen and Anthony Conti, was a surprisingly quick win for the Justice Department.
articles.abstract: The verdict against the two former Rabobank traders, Anthony Allen and Anthony Conti, was a surprisingly quick win for the Justice Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: A jury in Manhattan on Thursday found two former London traders guilty in the first convictions in the United States stemming from the global investigation into the rigging of an interest rate benchmark known as Libor.

articles.headline: Claims for Cryotherapy Treatment Get New Scrutiny After a Death
articles.snippet: A woman’s death in Nevada in October placed attention on the growing practice of full-body cryotherapy, which its enthusiasts say has many benefits.
articles.abstract: A woman’s death in Nevada in October placed attention on the growing practice of full-body cryotherapy, which its enthusiasts say has many benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — You step into an upright cylindrical capsule, padded on the inside and open on top. The floor grinds upward, and your head pops out. There’s a whoosh. And suddenly you are encased in gas, below the neck, in a tank that is minus 300 degrees Fahrenheit — colder than the coldest naturally occurring temperature recorded on Earth.

articles.headline: Exxon Mobil Investigated for Possible Climate Change Lies by New York Attorney General
articles.snippet: The sweeping inquiry focuses on whether the oil company lied to the public and investors over the risks of climate change.
articles.abstract: The sweeping inquiry focuses on whether the oil company lied to the public and investors over the risks of climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general has begun an investigation of Exxon Mobil to determine whether the company lied to the public about the risks of climate change or to investors about how such risks might hurt the oil business.
articles.byline: By Justin Gillis and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Dewey Jury’s Deadlock Exposes a System’s Flaws
articles.snippet: One reason for the mistrial in the Dewey & LeBoeuf criminal case may have been the requirement for a unanimous decision.
articles.abstract: One reason for the mistrial in the Dewey & LeBoeuf criminal case may have been the requirement for a unanimous decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the founding fathers enshrined a right to an impartial trial by jury in the Sixth Amendment, it’s hard to imagine they were anticipating the jury in the Dewey & LeBoeuf criminal case.

articles.headline: Ben Carson Appeals to Black Voters, but His Campaign Doesn’t, Yet
articles.snippet: Mr. Carson has a unique possibility of drawing blacks to vote in the Republican primary, but his campaign has yet to hire a staff member dedicated to turning out black voters.
articles.abstract: Mr. Carson has a unique possibility of drawing blacks to vote in the Republican primary, but his campaign has yet to hire a staff member dedicated to turning out black voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST MEMPHIS, Ark. — Sam Hawkins Jr. said he came to a rally here last week for the Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson because he finds Mr. Carson’s social conservatism appealing, relishes his newness to politics and believes that President Obama “sold out for the vote” in supporting same-sex marriage.

articles.headline: Congress Split on Tapping Fed or Banks to Fund Roads
articles.snippet: The Senate planned to raise money by paring back a bank dividend members see as obsolete, but the House wants to drain the Federal Reserve’s rainy-day fund instead. Critics say both ideas are wrongheaded.
articles.abstract: The Senate planned to raise money by paring back a bank dividend members see as obsolete, but the House wants to drain the Federal Reserve’s rainy-day fund instead. Critics say both ideas are wrongheaded.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The banking industry scored a surprise victory on Thursday when the House voted to pay for part of a new highway bill by draining a rainy-day fund at the Federal Reserve rather than cutting federal payments to some of the nation’s largest banks.

articles.headline: First President George Bush Swings at Son’s Aides, Rattling Clan
articles.snippet: Assertions in a new biography of the 41st president have exposed rifts in the Bush political dynasty. They have also complicated the efforts of another Bush, Jeb, to capture the White House.
articles.abstract: Assertions in a new biography of the 41st president have exposed rifts in the Bush political dynasty. They have also complicated the efforts of another Bush, Jeb, to capture the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President George Bush’s unusually sharp indictment of his son’s presidential advisers touched off a round of recriminations on Thursday that exposed rifts within America’s leading political dynasty and complicated its efforts to recapture the White House.

articles.headline: Strong Growth in Jobs May Encourage Fed to Raise Rates
articles.snippet: The economy added 271,000 jobs in October, an unexpectedly strong showing, and unemployment dipped to 5 percent.
articles.abstract: The economy added 271,000 jobs in October, an unexpectedly strong showing, and unemployment dipped to 5 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hiring at American companies shifted into higher gear in October, helping to lift wages and clearing the path for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates next month.

articles.headline: The Last Place on Earth With Ebola: Getting Guinea to Zero
articles.snippet: The deadliest Ebola epidemic in history has come down to a handful of cases in a cluster of villages, but efforts to end the outbreak have been uneven at best.
articles.abstract: The deadliest Ebola epidemic in history has come down to a handful of cases in a cluster of villages, but efforts to end the outbreak have been uneven at best.
articles.lead_paragraph: TANA, Guinea — Sirens blared as the convoy of government vehicles made its way down a narrow dirt road nearly encased by tall weeds. The prime minister had arrived, and he was there to give this rural community a serious scolding.

articles.headline: Toyota and Nissan to Drop Takata as Supplier of Airbag Inflaters
articles.snippet: The announcements are another blow to company, whose airbags generate about 40 percent of its sales.
articles.abstract: The announcements are another blow to company, whose airbags generate about 40 percent of its sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Customers are quickly rethinking their relationship with Takata, leaving the fate of its big airbag business in doubt.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Soble and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Square, Facing a Chilly Market, Persists in Pursuing I.P.O.
articles.snippet: The payments provider said it would sell shares at $11 to $13 apiece, a valuation of up to $4.2 billion — much lower than its private valuation.
articles.abstract: The payments provider said it would sell shares at $11 to $13 apiece, a valuation of up to $4.2 billion — much lower than its private valuation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest question on Wall Street on Friday was why Square, the upstart mobile payments company, was so determined to go public now.
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: A Family Team Looks for James Bond’s Next Assignment
articles.snippet: Barbara Broccoli and her half brother, Michael Wilson, who control the rights to James Bond, prepare for a battle royal over the franchise’s next studio home.
articles.abstract: Barbara Broccoli and her half brother, Michael Wilson, who control the rights to James Bond, prepare for a battle royal over the franchise’s next studio home.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the James Bond theme thundered — ba-da, ba-daaaa! — and 50 camera crews clamored for a better view, a white Suburban with tinted windows rolled up to the Americas premiere of “Spectre” on Monday in Mexico City. Swarming fans, many wearing Day of the Dead makeup, had been waiting for hours. Had the superspy himself finally arrived?
